props.title: Das Futur II (German Future Perfect tense): usage, conjugation and exercises

sections.content: 📚  The Präsens tense
Introduction
The Futur II  is the equivalent of the future perfect tense in English ("will have done"). It is used to express actions that will have been completed before a certain time in the future.

The Futur II  is not commonly used on everyday languages, except for literary contexts and, in spoken language, polite assumptions. Instead of Futur II, Germans often use the Perfekt or Präteritum with time markers (e.g., "Bis morgen habe ich es gemacht") or simply the Präsens tense.
Usage
We use the Futur II  tense to express:

items.text: Completion in the Future. To indicate that an action will be completed before another future action or time:

example.audio: Bis morgen Abend werde ich die Arbeit erledigt haben
example.text: Example: Bis morgen Abend $__werde-werden[verb-link-hover]__$ ich die Arbeit $__erledigt-erledigen[verb-link-hover]__$ $__haben-haben[verb-link-hover]__$
example.translation: (By tomorrow evening, I will have finished the work)

items.text: Assumptions about the Past. To make assumptions or speculations about something that might have happened in the past:

example.audio: Er wird wohl schon gegangen sein

items.text: Formal and literary contexts. While it is not as commonly used in everyday conversation, Futur II is more often seen in formal writing and literature.

sections.content: Conjugation

The Futur II  tense is formed with the present tense of the auxiliary verb $__werden-werden[verb-link-hover]__$ combined with the past participle of the main verb and the auxiliary verb "haben" or "sein".
It is a bit more complicated than other composed tenses, but do not worry, you just need to know the present tense of the verb "werden", how to form the "Partizip II" tense and learn the word order.
Word order
The word order for Futur II is:
[Subject] + werden (conjugated) + [other elements] + past participle + haben/sein (infinitive)
Refresing concepts
To form the Futur II tense, you need to know the present tense of the verb "werden", the Partizip II tense of the main verb, and when to use the auxiliary verbs "haben" and "sein".
The auxiliary verb "werden"
You must know the Präsens tense of the verb $__werden-werden[verb-link-hover]__$:

table.audio: ich werde, du wirst, (er) (sie) (es) wird, wir werden, ihr werdet, sie werden.

sections.content: practise präsens for werden
The Partizip II tense
The main verb takes the Partizip II tense, which is the past participle of the verb. You must know how to form it by now, but it is always good to refresh it if needed!
Train Partizip II with aleatory A1 level verbs
Auxiliary Verbs: 'haben' and 'sein'.</br>When to use each
The auxiliary verbs used on the Perfekt tense are $__haben-haben[verb-link-hover]__$ and $__sein-sein[verb-link-hover]__$:

items.text: $__Sein-sein[verb-link-hover]__$: Used with verbs that indicate a change of state or movement (e.g., 'gehen' - to go, 'kommen' - to come):

example.audio: Er wird nach Berlin gefahren sein.
